explanation: To determine whether OS_SelectSingle violates the MISRA rule against direct or indirect self-calls, the analysis must consider every function OS_SelectSingle calls and the functions those callees in turn call (to detect any path back to OS_SelectSingle). The listed symbols are the immediate callees of OS_SelectSingle (from the static graph) and their direct callees as given in the graph. Brief reasons: - OS_printf, OS_ConsoleWrite, UT_ExecuteVaHandler, UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData: OS_printf appears in OS_SelectSingle's call set (likely via a macro); if OS_printf or any of its callees can call back to OS_SelectSingle it creates indirect recursion. - OS_ObjectIdGetById and its helpers (OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit, OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex, OS_ObjectIdConvertToken, OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel): OS_SelectSingle calls OS_ObjectIdGetById; any of these helpers could (directly or via further calls) reach back to OS_SelectSingle. - OS_SelectSingle_Impl and its callees (OS_ObjectIndexFromToken, OS_DoSelect): OS_SelectSingle delegates to OS_SelectSingle_Impl; that implementation and its callees must be examined for calls back to OS_SelectSingle. - OS_ObjectIdRelease and OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish: OS_SelectSingle releases the token; the release path could include code that calls back into OS_SelectSingle. - UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType and UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr and their callees (UT_GetStubEntry, UT_ClearStubEntry, UtAssert_Abort, UtAssert_GetContext), plus UT_ExecuteBasicHandler, UT_SetHandlerFunction, UT_DefaultStubImpl: unit-test stub functions appear in the static call graph for OS_SelectSingle; they must be checked because stubs or assert helpers could (in the test environment) invoke other OS APIs that form a cycle. Examining these symbols (their definitions / call edges) is sufficient to trace all transitive calls originating from OS_SelectSingle in the provided static graph and to decide if any path returns to OS_SelectSingle (thus violating the MISRA rule).
